Data Engineering August 22, 2025 Data Droid

Lakehouse Table Formats: Delta Lake, Apache Iceberg, Apache Hudi

lakehouse delta-lake apache-iceberg apache-hudi table-format data-lake

📋 Table of Contents

  • 1. Introduction
  • 2. Delta Lake
  • 3. Apache Iceberg
  • 4. Apache Hudi
  • 5. Comparison of Three Platforms
  • 6. Use Cases and Selection Guide
  • 7. Conclusion

1. Introduction

The core of data lakehouse is combining the flexibility of existing data lakes with data warehouse features such as ACID transactions, schema evolution, data quality assurance, etc. What makes this possible is the Table Format.

The three most widely used table formats currently are:

  • Delta Lake - Open source project developed by Databricks
  • Apache Iceberg - Started by Netflix and moved to Apache Foundation
  • Apache Hudi - Developed by Uber and moved to Apache Foundation

💡 What is a Table Format?

A table format is a standardized way to manage metadata of data stored in data lakes and provide features such as ACID transactions, schema evolution, partitioning, and indexing. This allows data lakes to be used like data warehouses.

2. Delta Lake

2.1 Overview

Delta Lake is a table format open-sourced by Databricks in 2019, providing ACID transactions to data lakes through tight integration with Apache Spark.

🔗 Official Links

  • Official Website
  • GitHub Repository
  • Official Documentation
  • Blog

2.2 Key Features

  • ACID Transactions: Ensures atomicity, consistency, isolation, and durability
  • Schema Enforcement: Ensures data quality and integrity
  • Schema Evolution: Supports safe schema changes
  • Time Travel: Access to past data versions
  • Upsert/Merge: Efficient data updates
  • Open Format: Parquet-based, compatible with all tools

2.3 Architecture

Delta Lake Architecture

Application Layer
Spark SQL
Spark Streaming
BI Tools
↓
Delta Lake Engine
Transaction Log
Schema Management
ACID Guarantees
↓
Storage Layer
Parquet Files
Transaction Log
Checkpoint Files

2.4 Code Example

Delta Lake Basic Operations

# Write data to Delta table
df.write.format("delta").mode("overwrite").save("/path/to/delta-table")

# Read from Delta table
df = spark.read.format("delta").load("/path/to/delta-table")

# Update data
from delta.tables import DeltaTable
deltaTable = DeltaTable.forPath(spark, "/path/to/delta-table")
deltaTable.update(
  condition = "id = 1",
  set = {"value": "updated"}
)

# Time travel
df = spark.read.format("delta").option("versionAsOf", 0).load("/path/to/delta-table")

3. Apache Iceberg

3.1 Overview

Apache Iceberg is a table format designed for large analytical datasets, providing a clean abstraction over data files and metadata.

🔗 Official Links

  • Official Website
  • GitHub Repository
  • Documentation

3.2 Key Features

  • Hidden Partitioning: Automatic partition evolution
  • Schema Evolution: Safe schema changes
  • Partition Evolution: Change partition schemes without rewriting data
  • Version Rollback: Rollback to previous table versions
  • Multiple File Formats: Support for Parquet, ORC, Avro

3.3 Code Example

Iceberg Basic Operations

# Write to Iceberg table
df.writeTo("catalog.db.table").overwritePartitions()

# Read from Iceberg table
df = spark.read.table("catalog.db.table")

# Update table
spark.sql("""
  UPDATE catalog.db.table 
  SET value = 'updated' 
  WHERE id = 1
""")

# Rollback to previous version
spark.sql("CALL catalog.system.rollback_to_snapshot('catalog.db.table', 12345)")

4. Apache Hudi

4.1 Overview

Apache Hudi is designed for incremental processing and provides upserts and deletes on data lakes.

🔗 Official Links

  • Official Website
  • GitHub Repository
  • Documentation

4.2 Key Features

  • Upserts: Efficient insert/update operations
  • Incremental Processing: Process only changed data
  • Real-time Views: Read-optimized and real-time views
  • Clustering: Automatic data organization
  • Compaction: Automatic file optimization

4.3 Code Example

Hudi Basic Operations

# Write to Hudi table
df.write.format("hudi").options(
  hudi_options
).mode("overwrite").save("/path/to/hudi-table")

# Read from Hudi table
df = spark.read.format("hudi").load("/path/to/hudi-table")

# Incremental query
df = spark.read.format("hudi").option(
  "hoodie.datasource.query.type", "incremental"
).option("hoodie.datasource.read.begin.instanttime", "20230101").load("/path/to/hudi-table")

5. Comparison of Three Platforms

Feature Delta Lake Apache Iceberg Apache Hudi
Primary Use Case General purpose, Spark integration Large analytical datasets Incremental processing
ACID Transactions ✅ Full support ✅ Full support ✅ Full support
Schema Evolution ✅ Supported ✅ Advanced features ✅ Supported
Time Travel ✅ Version-based ✅ Snapshot-based ✅ Supported
Partition Evolution ❌ Limited ✅ Advanced ✅ Supported
Incremental Processing ✅ Supported ✅ Supported ✅ Specialized

6. Use Cases and Selection Guide

6.1 When to Choose Delta Lake

  • Already using Apache Spark ecosystem
  • Need tight integration with Databricks
  • Require ACID transactions on data lakes
  • Want simple setup and management

6.2 When to Choose Apache Iceberg

  • Working with large analytical datasets
  • Need advanced partition evolution
  • Want multiple engine support (Spark, Flink, Trino)
  • Require sophisticated schema management

6.3 When to Choose Apache Hudi

  • Primary focus on incremental processing
  • Need real-time data ingestion
  • Working with change data capture (CDC)
  • Require efficient upserts and deletes

💡 Selection Tips

Delta Lake: Best for Spark-based environments and quick setup
Apache Iceberg: Best for complex analytical workloads and multi-engine support
Apache Hudi: Best for real-time streaming and incremental processing

7. Conclusion

All three table formats provide excellent ACID transaction support and schema evolution capabilities, making them suitable for modern data lakehouse architectures. The choice depends on your specific use case, existing technology stack, and requirements.

Delta Lake

Best choice for Spark-based environments and Databricks users

Apache Iceberg

Best choice for complex analytical workloads and multi-engine support

Apache Hudi

Best choice for real-time streaming and incremental processing

As the data lakehouse ecosystem continues to evolve, these formats are becoming more interoperable, and you may find yourself using multiple formats for different use cases within the same organization.
